image.altText: Children at a desk colouring in.

props.synopsis: The NT opposition has criticised a government plan to direct unpaid truancy fines to be taken out of the Centrelink payments as a campaign of "fear and punishment" against parents and says the government doesn't have the jurisdiction to do it.

title.children: NT minister's plan to take truancy fines from Centrelink payments branded a 'scare tactic'

image.altText: A damaged, dark-coloured taxi in an impound.

props.synopsis: Police say the suspects are still at large amid calls for more to be done to address crime in the city.

title.children: Alice Springs taxis allegedly rammed, driver robbed twice in stolen ute rampage

image.altText: a graphic showing a male middle-aged police officer, a young man in a white collared shirt and a woman wearing a dress

props.synopsis: Every day of the coronial inquest into the death of Kumanjayi Walker, a sign reading "tell the truth" has stood outside the Alice Springs Local Court. Now, with final submissions heard, the NT coroner faces the task of finding that truth.

title.children: Coroner urged to find 'the truth' in Kumanjayi Walker case as inquest wraps up after two years

image.altText: Two people play pool in an outback pub.

props.synopsis: When tree-changers Frank and Debbie Wust bought the pub that starred in Crocodile Dundee just over a decade ago, they had no idea it also meant helping to run an outback community.

title.children: In the outback, running a pub means more than pouring beers

image.altText: A phone screen showing social media apps.

props.synopsis: From the end of next year, children under 16 will be banned from social media in Australia. So how do parents feel about enforcing the nation's controversial new laws?

title.children: For some parents, the 'blanket rule' of Australia's under-16 social media ban can't come soon enough

image.altText: an image of a qantas plane

props.synopsis: An exclusive, invite-only Qantas high-flyers club now includes more than half of the new NT government frontbench, with the politicians all receiving membership as gifts.

title.children: 'A place of entitlement': New NT ministers given exclusive Qantas Chairman's Lounge memberships

image.altText: a huge ship with beams and pipe-laying equipment

props.synopsis: Lawyers representing Tiwi Islanders trying to stop a gas pipeline running through their traditional sea country have been ordered to pay more than $9 million to gas giant Santos for its legal costs.

title.children: Lawyers for Tiwi Island group that tried to block gas project ordered to pay $9 million to Santos

image.altText: A woman rests her head on another woman's shoulder.

props.synopsis: It was two days before Christmas when Mary Malbiynga's little sister was killed by her partner at Darwin's famous Mindil Beach.

title.children: Screams for 20 minutes and no help. Inside the NT's domestic violence tragedy

image.altText: Ryan Kobayashi and two women hold pictures of missing woman Hannah Kobayashi.

props.synopsis: Hannah Kobayashi vanished somewhere in Los Angeles while on her way from Hawaii to New York City, and her father died days after arriving to search for her, leading to wild theories from online sleuths as authorities continue their investigations.

title.children: 'It's very peculiar': Why the disappearance of Hannah Kobayashi has gripped America

image.altText: A photo of a small, messy bedroom with two beds, a clothes horse and other furniture strewn around

props.synopsis: Sydney's housing crisis is evolving into a hidden health crisis and as rents soar, some residents face an impossible choice: unaffordable housing or unsafe living conditions.

title.children: 20 people in a two-bedroom apartment: the growing health and safety risks of 'hot bedding'

image.altText: Standing on the side of a road. Medium closeup framed to the right with trees and coloured park benches in the distance.

props.synopsis: The court case over a Facebook post is part of a long dispute between Liverpool Mayor Ned Mannoun and former councillor Peter Ristevski.

title.children: Social media post calling Liverpool mayor a 'crim' and 'grub' not defamatory, court rules

image.altText: An image of a middle-aged woman wearing a bright blue dress with blonde hair, standing outside near trees.

props.synopsis: Melissa Yarnold, a transgender woman, says nobody should have to go through what she experienced while in custody.

title.children: 'I was so scared': Trans woman speaks out over treatment in men's prison

image.altText: Barriers and barbed wire along the blue line, with a dirt road running near the border wall.

props.synopsis: The ABC takes you to the border between the two countries, hours after a ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah came into force.

title.children: Barbed wire, mud, concrete walls and burnt-out cars — the scars of war along the 'blue line'

image.altText: a photo of dr gwen on sharon's table

props.synopsis: Bedridden with rheumatic fever in the 1940s, and having already lost his father to the disease, Ian Braybrook says he owes his life to the big-hearted doctor who treated his family without charge.

title.children: She saved his life, so he spent years unravelling the mystery of the 'gentle lady who dressed like a bushwhacker'

image.altText: A soldier on a motorbike drives down a long road with houses and smoke rising at the end

props.synopsis: Syrian insurgents have taken control of parts of Aleppo, while Russian air strikes have continued to pound rebel areas, killing at least 277 people.

title.children: Syrian rebels reportedly take control of parts of Aleppo in shock offensive

image.altText: A man wearing a turban.

props.synopsis: Hezbollah chief Naim Qassem has declared his organisation has scored a "divine victory" in its year-long war with Israel that paused as part of a ceasefire deal last week.

title.children: Hezbollah chief says group has scored 'divine victory' against Israel

image.altText: a group exercises on bikes at a weight loss camp

props.synopsis: Beijing has launched a three-year plan to tackle obesity, with rates of overweight children and adults rapidly increasing in just a few years.

title.children: 'Really scary': Chinese obesity rates surge and expected to rival US

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses leaves a court house.

props.synopsis: A family member of the victims tells a Tasmanian court: "I didn't just lose my mum and brother … I lost my family unit and I lost myself. I will never be me again."

title.children: Off-duty police officer who caused crash that killed mother and son avoids jail

image.altText: A woman's hands flick through a thick stack of paperwork.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's Legal Aid Commission has been handed an almost $4 million funding boost, which will prevent looming service cuts that threatened to bring the territory's strapped justice system to its knees.

title.children: Funding lifeline handed to NT Legal Aid to prevent looming service cuts

image.altText: Darwin Port sign behind barbed wire.

props.synopsis: The PwC report found a "material uncertainty" about Landbridge's "ability to continue as a going concern" at the port.

title.children: Financial audit casts 'significant doubt' on Chinese-owned company's 99-year Darwin Port lease

image.altText: A young man walking through a gate holding a washing basket full of recyclable materials.

props.synopsis: Callum Darch's car boot is full when he heads off on the 420 km trip to see his parents in Perth. But its contents might come as a surprise.

title.children: As most Aussies take their recycling to the front door, Callum stockpiles his and saves it for a trip to the city

image.altText: A composite picture of a woman in black-and-white and a man in colour, both looking serious.

props.synopsis: The decisions the Reserve Bank makes affect the rest of us, and therefore should continue not to be taken lightly — whichever board might make them.

title.children: The struggle over Australia's economic outlook is being fought in the shadows

image.altText: A shot of a busy Melbourne street with pedestrians in front of a tram.

props.synopsis: COVID-19 cases and hospitalisations have sharply risen in Victoria, with the wave of infection concerning health professionals going into summer.

title.children: COVID-19 wave hits Victoria, prompting calls for caution ahead of festive season

image.altText: Three young women stand in front of a large tree smiling. The lady in the middle holds a baby kangaroo in a pink pouch

props.synopsis: Regional veterinary jobs are taking more than 12 months to fill, but a Riverland clinic has found a short-term solution to boost workforce and mental health outcomes.

title.children: There are lots of snakes and it's 'the size of Belgium', but this region desperately needs its foreign vets

image.altText: A woman stands infront of a rose bush holding a photo of her mother and father smiling

props.synopsis: Wendy Robinson's parents were shot dead 10 years ago. She is distressed their killer is starting to get some of his freedoms back and believes he is "being treated better" than his victims' family.

title.children: Wendy's parents were murdered. She says their killer's privileges in a forensic hospital worsen her grief

image.altText: A man stands shirtless pouring 2 litres of iced coffee over his face and body

props.synopsis: A group of Gold Coast concreters have put down the tools to strip off for a lighthearted 2025 calendar, to raise funds and awareness for men's mental health.

title.children: Unlikely models strike a pose for mental health awareness calendar

image.altText: A security guard wears a rain poncho at Manuka Oval with Prime Minister's XI displayed on the screen behind him.

props.synopsis: The first day of the pink-ball tour game between the Prime Minister's XI and India is washed out, robbing Aussies and Indian stars of a chance for some much-needed practice ahead of the second Test in Adelaide.

title.children: Scott Boland and Indian stars denied pink-ball outing as rain washes out day 1 of PM's XI clash

image.altText: Police tape at a crime scene

props.synopsis: A man has died after crashing his car through the back wall of a supermarket in Melbourne's south-east.

title.children: Man dead after car crashes through Melbourne supermarket wall

image.altText: Scaffolding around the Notre Dame cathedral, backgrounded by blue sky

props.synopsis: The bells of Notre Dame are chiming again, but scaffolding still clinging to the cathedral's exterior is puzzling some Parisians.

title.children: Notre Dame is finally reopening after a devastating 2019 fire. But why does it still look unfinished?

image.altText: A bettong wrapped inside a cream coloured soft bag

props.synopsis: After being driven to extinction in the area, these tiny brush-tailed bettongs were reintroduced to South Australia's Yorke Peninsula as part of an ambitious project to help nature heal itself — and evidence of their eco-engineering can already be seen.

title.children: The tiny engineers helping nature heal itself

image.altText: Golfer Jiyai Shin puts a fist in the air at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: Jiyai Shin's stunning finish hands her a lead over Aussie hope Hannah Green, while Ryggs Johnston, named after Mel Gibson's character from the Lethal Weapon franchise, shares top spot in the men's event with Victorian Lucas Herbert.

title.children: Lethal Weapon strikes as late magic vaults Jiyai Shin to top at the Australian Open

image.altText: A woman surrounded by other pro-independence demonstrators holds up a Kanak flag behind her back.

props.synopsis: The European power spends billions of euros on New Caledonia and faces a large damage bill from this year's violent unrest. Why is it hanging on?

title.children: Why is one of Australia's closest neighbours still part of France?

image.altText: Eight books covers sit on a pale background, including Niall Williams Time of the Child and Inga Simpson's The Thinning.

props.synopsis: If you're looking to stack up your summer reading pile, here's an excellent starting point, with new releases from Rosalie Ham, Lech Blaine, Haruki Murakami and more.

title.children: Planning a summer of great reading? Here are our recommendations

image.altText: Bushfire smoke blows behind a series of beehives.

props.synopsis: As the fight against a massive bushfire north of Perth continues, honey producers have reported devastating losses to habitat critical for their bees.

title.children: 'That is all gone now': Honey producers say WA bushfire has incinerated critical bee habitat
